block.p: Milton Viorst says the United States should take a hard line to ''curb Israel's advantage'' in negotiations with the Palestinians (Op-Ed, May 24). This is unrealistic in an American presidential election year, but also unwise.

In the aftermath of Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon, playing tough may invite attempts by Syria, Iran and the Hezbollah to take action against Israel proper. Does anyone doubt that Israel would respond strongly to any attacks, which could then plunge the region into warfare?

Milton Viorst says the United States should take a hard line to ''curb Israel's advantage'' in negotiations with the Palestinians (Op-Ed, May 24). This is unrealistic in an American presidential election year, but also unwise.

In the aftermath of Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon, playing tough may invite attempts by Syria, Iran and the Hezbollah to take action against Israel proper. Does anyone doubt that Israel would respond strongly to any attacks, which could then plunge the region into warfare?

I believe that the Palestinians are entitled to their own state, but backing Prime Minister Ehud Barak's intentions of completing a peace deal by reinforcing him politically and diplomatically may be a better way to achieve that.
